comments:
This just started with the Eclipse I20040226 driver. When you launch
self-hosting using PDE, even though it launched correctly, the fact that it is a
self-hosting launch is lost. When it finally comes up none of the classloaders
in the bundles are using the bin directory of the supplied plugins from the
development workspace. They are pointing instead to the plugins that came out of
the target platform.

If you look at the command line when launched it is correct. It is on the
launched side that seems to be ignoring the -dev bin flag.

This makes development impossible because you can't get it to execute your
development code.

Thanks,
Rich

In the program arguments, check the value of the "-configuration" arg.  Then 
navigate to that directory while your runtime workbench is up, and locate the 
platform.xml/platform.cfg in it and attach it to this bug report to answer the 
age old question:  where do plug-ins come from?

actually, never mind.
The problem is that the 0226 build contains a breaking change in Update where 
they changed their platform configuration file name from platform.cfg to 
platform.xml.

PDE has a backward compatibility in the this week's I-build.  Get 0302 or 0303.

Do I need the 0302 driver for the target platform or for the development platform?

It is important because I'm not ready to step up to that driver as my
development platform. I don't feel comfortable using it for all of my code. It
has a big bug (https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=53095 ) that makes
debugging very difficult.

Here is the thing: 0225/0226 are the breaking point.

I'm not sure what your target platform, but I'm talking about what to use for 
the host platform.

If your target platform is based on a build that is < 0225, then either use 
that same build as host platform or use 0303 as host (which you don't seem to 
want because of the JDT/Core bug).

If your target platform is >= 0225, then you should use >=0225 as host 
platform.  Of course, there is no forward compatibility from pre-0225 builds 
to account for the breaking change in Update.

For me using 0226 to host 0226 I get the following error from the launcher.

!SESSION ----------------------------------------------------------------------
!ENTRY org.eclipse.core.launcher 4 0 Mar 03, 2004 17:28:20.206
!MESSAGE Exception launching the Eclipse Platform:
!STACK
java.lang.IllegalStateException: Bundle 
reference:file:C:/dev_eclipse_m7_05/eclipse/plugins/org.eclipse.osgi.util_3.0.0
/ [2] is not active
	at org.eclipse.core.runtime.adaptor.EclipseStarter.ensureBundlesActive
(EclipseStarter.java:123)
	at org.eclipse.core.runtime.adaptor.EclipseStarter.run
(EclipseStarter.java:93)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke
(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:39)
	at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke
(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:25)
	at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:324)
	at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.basicRun(Main.java:279)
	at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.run(Main.java:742)
	at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.main(Main.java:581)
Jeff, have you seen this one recently?

this usually has to do with a bogus configuration of some sort.  Was this a 
fresh install, not unziped over another one, not manually tweaked, tickled or 
primped?

My sense is this must be something in your setup since most of the people here 
have been using this sort of configuration for the last week with no major 
problems.
I did a clean install and things work great.  Tks for the help.
